children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

31.I.1	The International Civil Service Commission (ICSC) was established pursuant to General Assembly resolution 3357 (XXIX) and is responsible for the regulation and coordination of the conditions of service for the United Nations common system. Under its statute, the Commission is a subsidiary organ of the Assembly. In the exercise of its functions, the Commission is guided by the principles set out in the agreements between the United Nations and other organizations aimed at the development of a single unified international civil service through the application of common personnel standards, methods and arrangements.
Programme of work
Objective
31.I.2	The objective, to which ICSC contributes, is to ensure fair and harmonized conditions of service for staff in the United Nations common system.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
31.I.3	To contribute to the objective, the Commission will:
(a)	Continue to develop and strengthen a common system of salaries, allowances and benefits under the Noblemaire and Flemming principles;
(b)	Apply the methodologies for determining salaries and post adjustment classifications;
(c)	Provide guidance and advice on the administration of human resources management policies and systems, including job evaluation standards and tools, for all stakeholders;
(d)	Lend its expertise to stakeholders and work closely with the Human Resources Network of the United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination (CEB);
(e)	Seek feedback from organizations on the conditions of service of staff;
(f)	Conduct workshops to educate staff on the work of the Commission and on the benefits and entitlements available to staff of the United Nations common system;
(g)	Monitor and report to the General Assembly on the implementation of its decisions by common system organizations, and recommend appropriate measures to ensure compliance;
(h)	Analyse the conditions of service of staff in difficult duty stations;
(i)	Periodically conduct comprehensive reviews of the common system compensation package;
(j)	Explore options for non-financial incentives for staff of the common system.

31.I.4	In an effort to increase diversity and rejuvenate the workforce within the common system, the Commission will continue monitoring trends in the common system organizations and propose relevant updates to the General Assembly on any new developments as they relate to geographical diversity and the rejuvenation of the workforce.
31.I.5	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	The promotion of geographical diversity and rejuvenation of the workforce;
(b)	A coherent, attractive and effective common-system human resources management system that is aligned closely with the achievement of organizational goals and objectives;
(c)	Adequate conditions of service for all categories of staff.

31.I.6	With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the planning assumption that organizations of the United Nations common system provide timely information, as requested by the Commission, and that they fully implement the Commission’s decisions and recommendations.

31.I.7	With regard to cooperation with other entities at the global, regional, national and local levels, the Commission will continue to conduct reference checks with other international organizations to ascertain whether the organizations of the common system remain competitive and continue to be attractive on the labour market.

31.I.8	With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, within the United Nations common system, the Commission will continue to engage with staff and heads of common system organizations through various forums. Engaging with staff and management of the various organizations will strengthen existing partnerships and lead to greater cooperation among stakeholders and full implementation of decisions and recommendations of the Commission and the General Assembly. This will also contribute to the timely completion of reviews requested of the Commission.

31.I.9	The Commission integrates a gender perspective in its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. In 2026, the Commission will update the General Assembly on the implementation of existing gender parity policies in the United Nations common system and report on the implementation of the Commission’s recommendations. The Commission will also conduct an assessment and review of the implementation of the parental leave framework, in accordance with General Assembly resolution 77/256 A–B.

31.I.10	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Commission will continue to review the methodology and level of the allowance for a child with disabilities in conjunction with children’s and secondary dependants’ allowances and consider any additional measures in the context of the ongoing comprehensive review.
Programme performance in 2024
Greater consistency among United Nations common system organizations on the application of post adjustment multipliers

31.I.11	In its resolution 74/255 B, the General Assembly expressed concern at the application of two concurrent post adjustment multipliers in the United Nations common system at the Geneva duty station and noted with concern that the organizations of the common system faced the challenge of having two independent administrative tribunals with concurrent jurisdiction among organizations of the common system. Following several consultations by the Commission and the Secretary-General with the Fifth and Sixth Committees of the General Assembly, the Assembly, in its resolution 77/256 A, decided to amend articles 10 and 11 of the statute of the Commission and reaffirmed the authority and competence of the Commission to establish post adjustment multipliers for duty stations in the United Nations common system, under article 11 (c) of the statute. The Assembly, in the same resolution, invited common system organizations to complete, as quickly as practicable, formal acceptance of the amended statute and called upon all organizations that had not done so to implement the post adjustment multipliers established by the Commission, based on the results of the 2021 baseline cost-of-living surveys. The Commission engaged closely with common system organizations to promote implementation of the Assembly’s decisions. By the end of 2024, 24 out of 28 organizations had formally adopted the changes to the Commission’s statute.
31.I.12	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (table 31.I.1).
Table 31.I.1
Performance measure

Result 1: a common system compensation package that is fit for purpose, competitive and cost-efficient – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

children.text: Result 3: revised standards of conduct to guide organizations on emerging issues – Proposed programme plan for 2026

31.I.17	The standards of conduct for the international civil service were first issued in 1954 and were intended to be a behavioural and ethical guide to inform and inspire staff. The passage of time and the emergence of new ethical challenges have created a need for clearer standards in relation to contacts outside the common system and more transparent accountability systems. The standards were reissued in 1986 and revised in 1998, 2001 and 2012. In 2022, the Commission decided to revise the current standards to ensure that they continued to meet the needs of the organizations. The focus was on external interactions, including political activities and conflict of interest; internal issues such as abuse of authority, harassment, all forms of violence, strengthening of accountability, duty of care and staff-management relations; and emerging issues. The Commission created a working group comprising staff, organizations and the Commission and will present the changes in its 2025 annual report, for roll-out in 2026.
Lessons learned and planned change

31.I.18	The lesson for the Commission was that any preliminary findings when undertaking such reviews should be shared widely with relevant legal offices within common system organizations before finalizing any changes. In applying the lesson, the Commission will continue to proactively engage with legal experts within the organizations to solicit their views prior to publication so that changes can be implemented by organizations, subject to their approval by the General Assembly.
31.I.19	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 31.I.4).
Table 31.I.4

children.text: B.	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026
Overview (jointly financed resources)
31.I.22	The proposed jointly financed resources for 2026, including the breakdown of resource changes, as applicable, are reflected in tables 31.I.6 to 31.I.8.
Table 31.I.6
Overall: evolution of financial resources by object of expenditure (jointly financed)
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 31.I.7
Note: The following abbreviations are used in tables and figures: GS (OL), General Service (Other level); GS (PL), General Service (Principal level).
Overall: proposed posts and post changes for 2026 (jointly financed)
(Number of posts)
Table 31.I.8
Overall: proposed posts by category and grade (jointly financed)
(Number of posts)
31.I.23	Additional details on the distribution of the proposed resources for 2026 are reflected in table 31.I.10 and figure 31.I.I.

31.I.24	As shown in table 31.I.6, the overall resources proposed for 2026 amount to $13,393,100, reflecting no change compared with the approved budget for 2025. The proposed level of resources provides for the full, efficient and effective implementation of mandates.

31.I.25	In accordance with article 21 of the statute of the Commission, the budget estimates have been established after consultation with the Finance and Budget Network of the High-level Committee on Management of CEB conducted in March 2025. In the light of the ongoing significant financial constraints faced by United Nations system entities, in January 2025 the Network issued guidance to the jointly financed activities entities in formulating their 2026 budget proposals, noting that it was imperative that the 2026 budget formulation process reflect fiscal prudence and align with the financial realities of contributing organizations. To enable informed decision-making and flexibility in addressing financial constraints, the Network requested each jointly financed activities entity to submit to it two budget scenarios for 2026: one at zero growth and one with a 20 per cent reduction compared with the 2025 approved budget levels, with the caveat that if there were no vacant posts, the 20 per cent reduction might be applied to non-post resources only. That two-scenario approach was intended to enhance awareness among jointly financed activities entities of the financial challenges faced by contributing agencies, while ensuring a transparent, consultative and impact-driven decision-making process for the 2026 budgets. The Network reviewed the budget proposed by the Commission for 2026 and welcomed an initial proposal for a 5 per cent reduction, the Commission having indicated that achieving the requested 20 per cent reduction would be challenging without compromising its core functions. The Network nevertheless noted that there were clear opportunities for further reductions, including with respect to vacant posts in the Commission secretariat and with regard to travel, and requested the Commission to take the most prudent measures possible in finalizing the 2026 budget proposal for consideration by the General Assembly. The proposed resources for 2026 that are shown in the present budget submission are at the same level as those approved for 2025, as finalized by the Commission, with cost-neutral redeployments of resources mainly from general operating expenses to contractual services and travel of representatives.

31.I.26	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which the organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, ICSC is integrating environmental management practices into its operations. In 2026, the Commission will continue its online repository, where most of its survey materials are deposited, and continue to encourage meeting participants to gain access to documents online, and, where not possible, documents have been emailed to meeting participants. Furthermore, with the use of Microsoft Teams, documents are shared with participants without the need to print hard copies. This has significantly reduced the number of documents printed and mailed.

31.I.27	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 31.I.9. The lower travel compliance rate was due to last-minute requests from organizations for the Commission to participate in meetings and training and late decisions by Commission members to attend meetings owing to their own obligations, as well as late visa approval for some Commission members. The Commission is faced with difficulty when staff and members of the Commission are invited to meetings on very short notice to discuss issues affecting staff in the United Nations common system.
Table 31.I.9
Compliance rate
(Percentage)

children.text: 31.I.28	The proposed regular budget resources for 2026 amount to $5,147,000 and reflect an increase of $53,200 (or 1.0 per cent) compared with the approved budget for 2025. As shown in table 31.I.11, resource changes result from technical adjustments ($53,200) due to an increase in the United Nations Secretariat share of the budget of the Commission, from 38.0 per cent for 2025 to 38.4 per cent for 2026, as determined by the CEB secretariat in accordance with the established methodology.
A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

31.II.1	The Joint Inspection Unit is mandated, through its statute, as contained in General Assembly resolution 31/192, to review matters bearing on the efficiency of services and the proper use of funds and to provide an independent view aimed at improving management and methods and at achieving greater coordination among the organizations of the United Nations system. The Unit performs inspections and evaluations and issues reports and notes in which it identifies best practices, proposes benchmarks and facilitates information-sharing among all the organizations of the United Nations system that have adopted its statute.
Programme of work
Objective
31.II.2	The objective, to which the Joint Inspection Unit contributes, is to improve the efficiency, effectiveness and coordination of the United Nations system.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
31.II.3	To contribute to the objective, the Joint Inspection Unit will:

(a)	Ensure that its programme of work includes system-wide reviews in the identified main thematic areas: accountability and oversight functions and systems; management and administration practices; the implementation of policies, strategies and programmes, as well as coordination and collaboration on the realization of internationally agreed development goals, such as the Sustainable Development Goals; and governance arrangements and mechanisms, as well as inter-agency coordination;

(b)	Undertake system-wide reviews of the management and administration practices and methods of the organizations of the United Nations system in the areas of human and financial resources, administration, results-based management, strategic planning and management, change management, risk management, security and safety and information technology;
(c)	Focus on system-wide issues that can be assessed across all or multiple organizations in conducting its reviews, as well as management and administrative reviews of individual organizations;
(d)	Develop and implement effective platforms for the sharing of good practices and knowledge in the various thematic areas of the work of the Unit;

(e)	Analyse the acceptance and implementation of the Unit’s recommendations to establish how rates of acceptance and implementation can be improved and how consideration of the Unit’s reports by legislative organs can be more effective.
31.II.4	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Better information for legislative body decision-making;
(b)	Improved efficiency and effectiveness of the organizations of the United Nations system;
(c)	Improved coordination and collaboration of the organizations of the United Nations system.

31.II.5	With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the planning assumption that participating organizations fully cooperate with the reviews of the Joint Inspection Unit and that recommendations are accepted and implemented.

31.II.6	With regard to coordination and cooperation within the United Nations system, the Unit will continue its engagement in various forums, including with the Board of Auditors, the Office of Internal Oversight Services and the audit and oversight committees of participating organizations. The engagement of a broad range of actors, including those beyond the traditional inspection sphere, is critical to mobilizing effective responses and pursuing solutions to improve business processes. This means the continued strengthening of existing partnerships with independent internal oversight entities and oversight committees in participating organizations, but also pursuing new ones that can help to foster innovative approaches. The Unit will pursue measures to continue to promote an integrated approach to support the implementation of the recommendations included in its reports.

31.II.7	The Joint Inspection Unit integrates a gender perspective in its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. The Unit will continue to examine and report on the gender policies and practices of organizations that it has identified for its management and administration reviews.

31.II.8	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Joint Inspection Unit will also continue to accelerate the effective mainstreaming of disability inclusion, including mitigating measures to overcome any challenges while operationalizing disability inclusion.
Programme performance in 2024
Greater visibility and transparency in the selection of review topics

31.II.9	During the Unit’s self-assessment exercise, participating organizations were consulted extensively. One of the observations recorded was that a more structured assessment of topics, using a set of explicit criteria, was needed as a basis for choosing the system-wide topics for review. The Unit developed selection criteria to assess the Unit’s topics that included risk, priority, value for money and coordination enhancement, and also developed a scoring template to record inspectors’ assessment of topics against the criteria. The criteria and scoring template were approved by inspectors and added as an annex to the internal working procedures. The application of the selection criteria in 2024 for the 2025 programme of work assures participating organizations and stakeholders of an objective basis for topic selection.
31.II.10	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 31.II.1).
Table 31.II.1
Performance measure

table_content.text: Greater visibility and transparency for participating organizations in the selection of review topics

children.text: Planned results for 2026
Result 1: timely availability of reviews to enable appropriate action by participating organizations to implement recommendations – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026
31.II.11	The Unit’s work contributed to the availability of 100 per cent of reviews carried over from the previous year, which met the planned target.
31.II.12	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 31.II.I).
Figure 31.II.I
Performance measure: availability of reviews carried over from the previous year (annual)
(Percentage)

Result 2: enhanced management of administrative and programmatic issues by organizations of the United Nations system through the implementation by the Joint Inspection Unit of strategic and operational recommendations – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

31.II.13	The Unit’s work contributed to the improved usefulness and impact of the Unit’s reports for the organizations of the United Nations system, through the improved formulation of recommendations that better identified the required elements (i.e. what, by whom, when and for what result/impact) and through the establishment of a process for participating organizations to provide inputs on draft recommendations, which met the planned target.
31.II.14	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 31.II.2).
Table 31.II.2
Performance measure

table_content.text: Improved usefulness and impact of Joint Inspection Unit reports for organizations of the United Nations system through more efficient and enhanced data collection and data analytics

Improved usefulness and impact of the Unit’s reports for organizations of the United Nations system through improved formulation of recommendations that better identified the required elements (i.e. what, by whom, when and for what result/impact)

Improved usefulness and impact of the Unit’s reports for organizations of the United Nations system through outreach and communications to ensure that the results of its reports are disseminated across the United Nations system organizations and to Member States
Improved reporting on the acceptance, implementation and intended impact of the Unit’s recommendations by organizations of the United Nations system

children.text: Result 3: strengthened impact of Joint Inspection Unit recommendations – Proposed programme plan for 2026

31.II.15	The value and impact of the recommendations made in the Unit’s products (reports and notes) are realized when they are accepted and implemented by the participating organizations. The Unit has developed its strategic framework to focus on key intended impact areas for recommendations. The framework seeks to ensure that the Unit balances the mix of recommendations in order to have an intended impact that focuses on selected areas for the participating organizations.
Lessons learned and planned change

31.II.16	The lesson for the Unit was that it was necessary to refine the proportion and distribution of the intended impact of recommendations in order to strengthen the focus on certain identified areas. In applying the lesson, the Unit will target recommendations that will have a greater intended impact in certain areas, such as transparency and accountability; effectiveness; efficiency; and dissemination of good practices.
31.II.17	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 31.II.3).
Table 31.II.3
Performance measure: proportion of recommendations with intended impact in the identified areas

table_content.text:
26 per cent: enhanced transparency and accountability
23 per cent: enhanced effectiveness

31.II.21	Additional details on the distribution of the proposed resources for 2026 are reflected in table 31.II.9 and figure 31.II.II.

31.II.22	As shown in table 31.II.5, the overall resources proposed for 2026 amount to $9,666,200, reflecting a net decrease of $170,400 (or 1.7 per cent) compared with the approved budget for 2025. Resource changes result from technical adjustments. The proposed level of resources provides for the full, efficient and effective implementation of mandates.

31.II.23	In accordance with article 20 of the statute of the Joint Inspection Unit, the budget estimates have been established after consultation with the Finance and Budget Network of the High-level Committee on Management of CEB conducted in March 2025. The Network reviewed the budget proposed by the Unit for 2026, following the same process as outlined in paragraph 31.I.25 above for the Commission. The Network expressed appreciation with a 26 per cent budget reduction in non-post resources proposed by the Unit, which is due to the removal of non-recurring items budgeted in 2025. The proposed resources for 2026 shown in the present budget submission are as proposed by the Unit.

31.II.24	As shown in table 31.II.9, resource changes result from technical adjustments (decrease of $170,400) under furniture and equipment, reflecting the removal of non-recurrent resources approved for 2025 for the replacement of the Unit’s web-based tracking system and the purchase of a new conferencing system.

31.II.25	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, the Unit will continue to reduce its carbon footprint by reducing the quantity of documentation printed, as well as by limiting travel and maximizing the use of possible alternatives to face-to-face meetings, whenever feasible.

31.II.26	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 31.II.8. The Unit requires that, for each of its review projects, a travel plan be submitted to facilitate the advance purchase of the related air tickets. Better advanced planning has enabled the Unit to be almost fully compliant with the target requiring air tickets to be purchased at least two weeks in advance of travel, thus guaranteeing lower travel costs.

Compliance rate

children.text: 31.II.27	The proposed regular budget resources for 2026 amount to $2,631,900 and reflect a net decrease of $3,100 (or 0.1 per cent) compared with the approved budget for 2025. As reflected in table 31.II.10, resource changes result from technical adjustments and reflect a decrease of $46,400, representing the United Nations Secretariat share (27.2 per cent) of the reduction presented above under the jointly financed budget of the Unit ($170,400), offset in part by an increase in the United Nations Secretariat share of the budget of the Unit from 26.8 per cent for 2025 to 27.2 per cent for 2026 ($43,300), as determined by the CEB Secretariat in accordance with the established methodology.

text: III.	United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

31.III.1	CEB, composed of the Secretary-General and the executive heads of the organizations of the United Nations system, is responsible for promoting coherence, cooperation and coordination in the policies, programmes and activities of the organizations of the United Nations system in accordance with their mandates and in response to the decisions of intergovernmental bodies. The mandate of CEB derives from the priorities established in relevant General Assembly and Economic and Social Council resolutions and decisions, including Council resolution 13 (III) and decision 2001/321. At a time when the international community is confronted by increasingly complex and interrelated global challenges, coordinated and coherent action by the entities of the United Nations system is imperative. Mobilizing the system’s collective capacity is vital to supporting Member States in the integrated and accelerated implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the Pact for the Future, as well as the full range of mandates entrusted to United Nations system entities.
Programme of work
Objective
31.III.2	The objective, to which CEB contributes, is to leverage the collective capacity of the organizations of the United Nations system for the effective delivery of mandates.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
31.III.3	To contribute to the objective, CEB will:
(a)	Provide vision and leadership to guide the effective, coherent and coordinated implementation of mandates by United Nations system organizations;

(b)	Provide a forum for senior leaders of the United Nations system to agree on strategic action, enhance cooperation and pursue policy coherence in both programmatic and administrative areas and coordinate the use of resources, capacities and knowledge;
(c)	Through its High-level Committee on Programmes:
(i)	Foster strategic system-wide policy coherence and programme coordination in response to intergovernmental mandates and in support of internationally agreed development goals;
(ii)	Develop shared strategies, approaches and frameworks to address emerging policy and programme issues requiring system-wide action;
(d)	Through its High-level Committee on Management:

(i)	Accelerate the development of innovative approaches to improve efficiency and simplify and innovate business practices, fostering the harmonization, mutual recognition and integration of business operations, as well as encourage a coordinated approach to multilingualism across CEB member organizations;

(ii)	Utilize its functional networks on finance and budget, human resources, digitization and technology, procurement and safety and security to mainstream best practices, innovative management approaches and partnerships in all areas of management and to collect and publish comprehensive system-wide financial and human resources data.
31.III.4	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Accelerated progress towards the integrated and accelerated implementation of the 2030 Agenda by Member States and the full range of mandates entrusted to United Nations system entities, including the follow-up to and implementation of the Pact for the Future and its annexes;

(b)	A more coherent, coordinated and efficient United Nations system response to global challenges, such as setbacks to sustainable development, inequalities, threats to human rights, negative impacts of climate change and risks of new and emerging technologies;

(c)	Greater capacity of United Nations system organizations to provide effective management responses that drive systemic change in support of the delivery of mandates, through a focus on providing better data analytics; innovation and digital transformation; strategic foresight; and a work culture that encourages stronger results orientation;

(d)	Improved analytical quality of United Nations system-wide comprehensive, comparable financial and human resources data, evidence-based advancement of the ongoing ICSC comprehensive compensation review and enhanced transparency and accountability regarding system-wide financial flows.

31.III.5	With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the planning assumption that member organizations commit themselves and make timely contributions to the issues addressed by CEB.

31.III.6	CEB integrates a gender perspective in its activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate, including in the products of its high-level committees. The CEB annual human resources statistics will continue to present data on personnel of the United Nations system by category, grade and gender, helping to systematically track gender representation across the system. The CEB secretariat will continue to collaborate with the United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women (UN-Women) on tracking the financial contribution of United Nations activities to gender equality and the empowerment of women. In addition, the CEB secretariat will support the High-level Committee on Programmes in continuing to address gender equality and women’s empowerment in a cross-cutting manner, spanning the Committee’s agenda.

31.III.7	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the CEB High-level Committee on Management will continue to accelerate disability inclusion within organizations’ internal operations through the activities of its cross-functional networks.
Programme performance in 2024
Strengthened system-wide unity in support of climate action

31.III.8	The adverse impacts of climate change are felt by people everywhere, especially in developing countries. To bring the full weight of the United Nations system together for urgent climate action, the High-level Committee on Programmes developed and approved a set of strategic common messages to strengthen unity among organizations in support of ambitious outcomes at the twenty-ninth session of the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and beyond. The Committee rapidly coalesced around seven key priority areas for action, which included emission reductions and climate finance, thereby effectively harmonizing positions and facilitating synergies. As a dynamic product, the CEB-endorsed common messages continue to provide a shared narrative for the United Nations system to advocate for accelerated action to protect people and planet.
31.III.9	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 31.III.1).
Table 31.III.1
Performance measure

table_content.text: Strengthened unity, enabling the United Nations system to collectively promote key priorities and accelerated climate action for the benefit of people and planet

b 	See https://unsceb.org/sites/default/files/2025-01/Framework%20for%20a%20Model%20Policy%20on%20the%20%20
Responsible%20Use%20of%20AI%20in%20UN%20System.pdf.

Result 3: improved coherence of United Nations system activities for the acceleration of progress towards the Sustainable Development Goals and implementation of the Pact for the Future – Proposed programme plan for 2026

31.III.14	The Pact for the Future, a wide-ranging international agreement aimed at delivering a better future for people and planet, was adopted by the General Assembly at the Summit of the Future in September 2024 to accelerate progress towards achieving the Sustainable Development Goals while rising to new challenges and opportunities. The CEB secretariat supported processes under the High-level Committee on Programmes and the High-level Committee on Management to coordinate specific United Nations system contributions to intergovernmental deliberations preceding the Summit and to enhance United Nations system internal capacities. Each process enabled a common understanding and shared position among United Nations system entities. As a contribution to implementation of the Pact, United Nations organizations have to strengthen their capabilities to better deliver on their mandates and support Governments in meeting their commitments.
Lessons learned and planned change

31.III.15	The lesson for the CEB secretariat, based on its experience supporting activities in the lead-up to the Summit, was that coherence is best achieved through inclusive consultative processes among the United Nations system organizations, leveraging their diverse technical knowledge and experience. In applying the lesson, the CEB secretariat will support the two Committees in bringing together expertise spanning the United Nations to facilitate strategic system-wide policy coherence and coordination in programmatic and management areas of relevance across United Nations system mandates in order to contribute to accelerating progress towards the Sustainable Development Goals and implementing the Pact for the Future in a manner that complements activities being coordinated in other contexts.
31.III.16	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 31.III.4).

Overview (jointly financed activities)
31.III.19	The proposed jointly financed resources for 2026, including the breakdown of resource changes, as applicable, are reflected in tables 31.III.6 to 31.III.8.

(Number of posts)
31.III.20	Additional details on the distribution of the proposed resources for 2026 are reflected in table 31.III.10 and figure 31.III.I.

31.III.21	As shown in table 31.III.6, the overall resources proposed for 2026 amount to $4,522,600, reflecting a decrease of $179,500 (or 3.8 per cent) compared with the approved budget for 2025. Resource changes result from other changes.

31.III.22	Given that the activities of the CEB secretariat are jointly funded by agencies, funds and programmes of the United Nations common system, the budget estimates have been established after consultation with the Finance and Budget Network of the High-level Committee on Management of CEB conducted in March 2025. The Network reviewed the budget proposed by the CEB secretariat (including for the International Public Sector Accounting Standards (IPSAS) project) for 2026 following the same process outlined under paragraph 31.I.25 above for ICSC. The CEB secretariat presented two scenarios for 2026: one with a zero nominal growth and a second with an approximately 20 per cent reduction in non-post resources, as further detailed below. The Network endorsed the second scenario, with a 2026 budget level of $4,522,600 for the CEB secretariat (including $238,600 for the IPSAS project).

31.III.23	As shown in table 31.III.10, resource changes result from a reduction of $179,500 under other changes in compliance with a decision of the Finance and Budget Network on the level of resources for 2026 for the CEB secretariat, reflecting decreases under (a) other staff costs ($46,200) resulting from the downward reclassification of the temporary position for the IPSAS project from the P-5 to the P-3 level; (b) contractual services ($64,300); (c) general operating expenses ($22,400); (d) travel of staff ($17,000); (e) supplies and materials ($12,200); (f) furniture and equipment ($9,300); and (g) consultants ($8,100).

31.III.24	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, CEB is integrating environmental management practices into its operations. In 2026, in line with the Strategy for Sustainability Management in the United Nations System, 2020–2030, the CEB secretariat will continue to ensure that all meetings that it supports are single-use-plastic-free and paper-free to reduce waste and cut carbon emissions, as well as continue to promote an eco-friendly culture.

31.III.25	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 31.III.9. The CEB secretariat will continue to track compliance and to pursue the advance planning and nomination of travelling staff to meetings and conferences, whenever possible.

Table 31.III.11
Overall: evolution of financial resources (United Nations share)
(Thousands of United States dollars)

31.III.26	The proposed regular budget resources for 2026 amount to $1,337,800 and reflect a decrease of $70,700 (or 5.0 per cent) compared with the approved budget for 2025. As reflected in table 31.III.11, resource changes result from technical adjustments and other changes, as follows:

(a)	Technical adjustments: A decrease of $17,600 resulting from a reduction in the United Nations Secretariat share of the budget of the CEB secretariat from 29.9 per cent for 2025 to 29.6 per cent for 2026, as determined by the CEB secretariat in accordance with the established methodology;
(b)	Other changes: A decrease of $53,100, reflecting the United Nations Secretariat share (29.6 per cent) of the proposed decrease presented above under jointly funded resources ($179,500).

children.text: A.	International Civil Service Commission
B.	Joint Inspection Unit

C.	United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination

text: Annex II Summary of information on the cost-sharing methodology applied in establishing the United Nations share of jointly financed activities

children.text: 1.	The methodology applied since 1974 in respect of the cost-sharing of the International Civil Service Commission (ICSC) budget is based on the “Consultative Committee on Administrative Questions formula”, which apportions the ICSC costs on the basis of the number of staff, as contained in the personnel statistics published by the United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination (CEB) secretariat. The United Nations share of the costs also includes the shares for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East and the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, on the basis of the decision by the General Assembly that the costs relating to these two entities are funded from the regular budget of the United Nations.

2.	The methodology applied since 1996–1997 for the cost-sharing of the Joint Inspection Unit budget is derived from the expenditure reported in the audited accounts of the participating organizations, excluding:
(a)	Expenditure relating to peacekeeping;
(b)	Expenditure in kind, including the value of donated commodities;

(c)	A total of 50 per cent of the expenditure of the International Trade Centre corresponding to the share of the World Trade Organization, on the principle that the regular budget of the Centre is funded in equal parts by the United Nations and the World Trade Organization, which does not participate in the work of the Joint Inspection Unit.

3.	The methodology applied since 2006 for the cost-sharing of the CEB secretariat’s budget is based on 50 per cent of staff, in accordance with the most recently available personnel statistics, and 50 per cent of total expenditure, in accordance with the most recently available audited financial statements, minus expenditure in kind, excluding expenditure relating to peacekeeping operations.

4.	The methodology applied for the cost-sharing of the system-wide International Public Sector Accounting Standards budget is based on the same cost-sharing formula used to apportion the budget of the CEB secretariat, with the exclusion of the International Fund for Agricultural Development, which is not an active member in the International Public Sector Accounting Standards project.

text: Annex III Overview of financial and post resources

children.text: The jointly financed budgets of the International Civil Service Commission and the Joint Inspection Unit, as shown in the present budget submission, are for General Assembly consideration and approval, including the United Nations share. The jointly financed budget of United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination is presented for information purposes, while its United Nations share is presented for approval.
